title: Ticket #4486: Calling posix_memalign() prevents standard universe from linking.
description:
See CHTC-Requests #36960.

If a user program calls posix_memalign(), it will get the stock glibc implementation, which pulls in the stock glibc's malloc.o, which conflicts with our (mmap() -avoiding) implementation of malloc. The linker reports libcondor_c redefining symbols from libcondorsyscall (__libc_memalign, free, malloc, realloc).

We currently remap memalign() (the 'obsolete version' of posix_memalign(), according to the Linux man pages) to __libc_memalign() precisely to avoid this problem. It's therefore highly likely that remapping posix_memalign() to a memalign() wrapper function would solve this problem.
remarks:
2014-Jul-30 13:24:00 by tlmiller:
The following patch permits the link to occur. I also claim it implements posix_memalign() correctly, but I'll need help from the user to really test it properly. 

diff --git a/src/condor_syscall_lib/switches.remap-LINUX.h b/src/condor_syscall_
index b3d7ea3..ba8b6f4 100644
--- a/src/condor_syscall_lib/switches.remap-LINUX.h
+++ b/src/condor_syscall_lib/switches.remap-LINUX.h
@@ -778,19 +778,23 @@ int __wprintf_chk(int /* flag */, const wchar_t *format, .
 /* This forces malloc.o from libc.a to not be brought in, and allows stduniv
        code to use the malloc-user.c API instead */
 REMAP_TWO( memalign, __libc_memalign, void*, size_t, size_t )
-#endif
-
-#endif /* REMOTE_SYSCALLS */

+/* As above, except that our allocator doesn't provide posix_memalign(). */
+int posix_memalign( void ** ptr, size_t alignment, size_t size ) {
+       if( size == 0 ) { return NULL; }
+       if( alignment % sizeof(void *) != 0 ) { return EINVAL; }
+       // Zero is not a power of two.  Iff alignment is a power of two, it has
+       // a single one bit in position p; all other bits are zero.  Subtracting
+       // 1 from alignment causes the bit in position p to become zero.  Thus,
+       // alignment & (alignment - 1) is 0 iff alignment is a power of two.
+       if( (alignment == 0) || (alignment & (alignment - 1)) ) { return EINVAL; }
+       * ptr = memalign( alignment, size );
+       if( * ptr == NULL ) { return ENOMEM; }
+       return 0;
 }

+#endif

+#endif /* REMOTE_SYSCALLS */

-
-
-
-
-
-
-
-
+}

(No, that's not an extra right brace at the end of the patch. The whole header file is extern "C" {}, and diff decided I reused the former final right brace rather than inserting a new one.)
